headline: Rich and Simple French Onion Soup
description: This simple French onion soup is made rich with a broiled bread topping and three types of cheese, making it a perfect recipe choice for cold nights.

video.name: How to Make French Onion Soup | Get Cookin’ | Allrecipes.com

name: Rich and Simple French Onion Soup
recipeIngredient: 1 pinch salt and pepper to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Melt butter with olive oil in an 8-quart stock pot over medium heat. Add onions to butter and continually stir until tender and translucent. Do not brown the onions.
Add beef broth, sherry, and thyme. Season with salt and pepper. Let simmer for 30 minutes.

Ladle soup into oven-safe serving bowls and place one slice of bread on top of each (bread may be broken into pieces if you prefer). Layer each slice of bread with a slice of provolone, 1/2 slice diced Swiss and 1 tablespoon Parmesan cheese.
Place bowls on a cookie sheet and broil in the preheated oven until cheese bubbles and browns slightly, 2 to 3 minutes.

review.reviewBody: It was simple , it was delicous !!!! Thank you for sharing .....

This recipe makes no sense. At the top where it says "what is French onion soup?", it clearly states that it is a soup made with caramelized onions... but then the recipe says "do not brown the onions" You should also deglaze with the sherry before adding the beef stock.

Desperately needs the onions to be caramalised, brandy and white wine added along with alcohol burned off. Needs much more flavour. Weight of ingredients is much easier than silly cup sizes. All cups are different.
sounds yummy-I will be making this for sure

I cut it down for one serving by using one sliced onion, 1 c beef broth and a splash of sherry. I make my own bread, so used a thick slice of bread toasted and topped with parmesan and baby swiss (all I had on hand). Very tasty and quite satisfying!!
This soup is so easy and wonderful. I did carmelize the onions.

The soup was easy to make and delicious. I don't think it was necessary to use some oil with the butter, next time I will use only butter. I also added some red wine and a sprinkle of packaged onion soup. I will definitely make this soup again. Five stars!
Excellent! My family loved this soup. I followed the recipe exactly except for adding more salt.
It is a great recipe, but I use 2 cans of beef consumme and 3 cups of chicken stock instead of beef broth, gives it a better flavor

Amazing, I made this soup as a starter for the christmas dinner. It was prepared two days before and the flavor was just great. It takes very little effort to make but gives a great result. Will defenetly repeat soon!
Liked this one. We topped it with Gruyere cheese instead and added garlic to the soup, perfect for a cold winters night. I might add a red wine reduction for a richer taste next time.
love this recipe! Made it for my husband using my french onion soup crocks.The only change I made is that I caramelized the onions to get their best flavor. It was perfect!!
Easy peasy. Used beef onion soup mix on hand . My Alzheimers client loved it. Cubed the bread and made short slices of onion for easier spooning. Much more flavor than canned.
Great recipe. Only had garlic breadsticks so chopped that up and used Swiss cheese. Delicious! Thanks!

This was absolutely delicious! I followed the recipe but browned the onions for more flavour and took out some of the fat (1/4 cup butter and 2 tbsps olive oil is probably sufficient). I used no-salt broth, so added in 3/4 tsp salt and pepper to taste. Topped with French bread (made into croutons and browned in frying pan), Swiss cheese, and parmesan. My son said that this is the best thing that I've ever made. Added to my favourites. :)
Loved it nope didn't make no changes

This is very good. I did use 3 different alcohols: Dry Sherry, red wine, and brandy to add a more complex flavor, along with a Tb. of beef bouillon. Topped with French bread slices and a mound of gruyere cheese. A big hit in my house!
Very tasty! I would probably used 6 TBL of butter next time and leave it at that. I didn't add any oil and substituted the it with butter. It was good and I will be remaking it. Very easy too!

This was delicious! I did follow the advice of other reviews and brown/caramelize the onions. I did not fully caramelize them, but did more than just brown. The soup was almost better the second day as the flavors had melded even better! Overall, great! Will make again.
I like the basics of the recipe, but you have to caramelize the onions!
Delicious easy soup to make! I added sweet marsala instead of sherry and just a piece of toast with two cheeses I had in my refrigerator. So good, I will make this for a crowd next time!
I used a combination of white and red onions. Tasted awesome!
My younger brother and I love a good onion soup and I never thought to look up a recipe. This was delicious every time we visit it’s on the menu.

Simple and easy to make. My son asked for a second bowl, which did not surprise me as he is an onion freak. I reduced the amount of salt and used white pepper instead of black pepper. And I used locally produced German cheeses. Will be making again next month for a dinner party! Thanks for sharing!

Very bland!!! I should have read all the comments first! I did not brown the onions as the recipe calls for. A waste of time in the kitchen and effort. A beautiful dinner this was suppose to be with the soup being the first course but the soup is so bland it destroyed everything. Read all the comments first! Brown the onions!
We enjoyed this soup with friends for dinner. It was very easy to make and was delicious. We did add 2 tsp of minced garlic and 2 medium size bay leaves. Definitely worth making. Enjoy!!

The first time I made this recipe, my husband said, "this is exactly how French onion soup is supposed to taste." The only change I make is substituting Cider vinegar for the cooking sherry. The substitution amount is so small that I just put in a "glug" of vinegar.

I used 4 different types of onion, cooked the onions down then added 1.25 cups savignon blanc and 3TB of cooking sherry, 1tsp thyme and finished with slices provolone, baby swiss and shredded parmasan. Fantastic!
This was delicious. However, I also think it is too much butter and I feel the onions should be lightly browned for a deeper flavor.

It should be illegal to post a French onion soup recipe that specifically calls for NO CARMELIZATION. I made this soup without knowing any better at the time. It is flavorless, has severely under cooked blonde onions in it and a heart clogging, gag inducing amount of butter. Disappointed in the positive reviews.
I almost followed inggedients but finally made some changed. I used white dry wine instead of sherry. Cheese, i used only Provolone and important to use WHITE ONION

The recipe is a good base to start from. I did brown the onions to add richness to the recipe and substituted red wine for the sherry. Instead of putting it in regular bowls I used sourdough bread bowls and layered cheese on the bottom and the top. Turned out great!
Made it with fresh beef broth. Was delicious

The recipe as written = 3 stars. The way I ended modifying it = 5 stars.
1) increase the onions from 4 cups to 5 cups
2) BROWN the onions (that gives you MUCH greater depth of flavor)
3) increase the amount of BOTH the sherry & the thyme by 50%
I subbed the sherry for red wine and will definitely make this again. Yum!
Toast bread before it goes into the oven caramelize the onions..this soup is amazing!

I just started eating french onion soup recently. And I sometimes crave it. Lol so I decided to make it at home. This recipe was awesome. I do as other reviewers mentioned and you definitely have to Carmelize those onions, it is a must!!!! I added some garlic and used croutons instead of bread. Will make this again and again. Thanks for sharing.

This completely horrible. Please look at other recipes of this soup and see how many more ingredients are in it to make the broth taste good. I made this by accidentally opening up this recipe from Google and have spent the past hour fixing it. Unless you like to eat beef broth with thyme and onions - this recipe will taste horrible.

Very good recipe! The flavor is wonderful and the recipe guides you through nicely. After making it a few times now I've grown a bit more adventurous with my flavorings and expanded upon it with some added ingredients to really kick it up a notch! Great recipe to play with and practice a classic.

 I like adding some umami fish sauce, worchestershire sauce and balsamic vinegar for a slight kick, and a few more green herbs (savory /cilantro /oregano /basil /bay) to add depth. Thank you for the upload, my family loves it!
super easy recipe! Will definitely make again!
Too much butter. It deadens the onion taste. I would think half as much (1/4 C) would be enough. Otherwise good. Easy, clear directions.

Definitely the best French Onion soup I've (and my wife) have had in years.
Easy to make and really stellar!

It was really good, not to salty. I love french onion soup. Made some changes because didn't have everything. Used 2 onions did not brown them , instaed of Sherry used white cooking wine and a splash of red cooking wine added 1clove of garlic and only Swiss cheese and parmesan cheese both on bottom of bowl and on top ( the parmesan). Also used crispy croutons . My husband liked it also will be making it again. Enjoyed it today after this cold disaster we've had here in Houston.

I basically liked the recipe but also incorporated reviewers modifications as well. Cut the 1/2 cup of butter at least in half. I used 5 cups of sliced onions and felt caramelizing the onions added more flavor. I added another tablespoon of dry sherry. Toast the French bread so it doesn’t get soggy. Gruyere cheese is more flavorful than Provolone. The broth was rather bland so I added Knorr home style stock enhancer which made the stock taste richer.
We enjoyed the soup but noticed it was a lot better the next day.
I used Guyere a favorite of mine . Everything else was the same. We all loved it.

If you plan to caramelize the onions, I suggest not adding the 2 TBS of olive oil. It seems the olive oil prevents the onions from completely browning, which is really what releases their flavor and makes the soup scrumptious. Also, I think the amount of broth in the recipe makes the soup too watery. I cut back and still wanted to reduce the broth more. It's not as rich as I would like.

Cut the butter back to 6 tablespoons, because they were swimming in 8 Tbsps plus oil. Use spanish and vidiala (sweet) onion mix, as vidalia are not strong enough alone to hold this recipe up.
While the onions are cooking, add 1 teaspoon of honey. Helps with the carmelization and rounds out the flavor. 
Sprinkle 2 teaspoons of flour over the cooked onions and let cook 1 minute, stirring constantly before slowly adding broth.
I did not use garlic as husband does not like it, but it adds to the recipe so use if you can. 
Add worcesteshire. It makes a big difference.
The onions needed to be browned, the broth lacked a rich flavor.
Need to use salted butter and take away the olive oil.
Absolutely incredible! The first time I made this my wife declared it worthy for company! We both absolutely love it and will do it again and again.

We liked this. The juice was great, but my onions were chewy. Maybe I should have cooked them longer. I used 32 oz of beef broth and 16 oz of leftover chicken broth. 
Good enough to freeze what we didn't eat. Partner on diet, I ate the topping. Yum.
Great recipe, I made no changes
I loved it. It was easier then I expected. I used swiss cheese and garlic croutons.
Easy and simple but this soup lacks flavor. I suggest using beef bone broth instead of plain beef broth. You will get the rich onion and beefy flavor of most good onion soups.
Excellent and super easy. I substituted balsamic vinegar for the sherry and it hit the spot and left the house fragrant.
It turned out awesome.

This is a great recipe, made it and we loved it. I used Marsala because I didn’t have sherry and a take and bake garlic bread. I agree with other reviewers that I like my onions to be almost browned, lightly caramelized too.
It was The BOMB

The flavor of this recipe was very bland. We had to doctor it up quite a bit to get a flavor. We added 1/2 cup red wine, 2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce and 3 tsps of beef bouillon paste to give it flavor.

Following this recipe to a T resulted in a soup with way too much left over butter. You need to either significantly reduce the amount of butter or be okay with browning the onions (which is what most other recipes will tell you to do).
Sooooo good. Definitely adding it to our main cycle of meals!
Very good and easy to make.
the recipe was very simple to make, lots of flavor, I have to said that instead Sherry I used Pisco ( a peruvian liquor), and the result was fenomenal.
This was so good and easy to make! This is my mother’s favorite soup of all time and she said this was her favorite she has ever had! She was very impressed!

So this is a very basic, learning how to cook from the beginning recipe. The biggest issue with this recipe is how long they cook the onions for. You absolutely, positively MUST cook and caramelize the onions to a very deep, rich brown. If you can drag this process on as long as an hour to caramelize the onions, even better. This is where all the flavor comes from. The rest of the recipe is fine, you will find many variations of which alcohol to use, red wine, white wine, port, sherry, brandy. None are wrong, it's all about your taste, but please, CARAMELIZE THOSE ONIONS!!!!!!

I made this recipe- to a T... I don’t understand how so many people could have given this recipe 5 stars... you are supposed to caramelize the onions in French onion soup. I should have gone with my gut and just done that, I didn’t, it was very bad. Onion water soup topped with bread and cheese.

I made this last night, and it was delicious. The only changes I made, as others suggested, I did sauté the onions a bit longer and caramelized them. I toasted the bread a bit. Instead of cubing the swiss cheese, I laid a half slice on top of the provolone. And I think I used more parmesan cheese than what was called for. I also used dry red cooking wine, as that's what I had on hand. Otherwise, it was very delicious! My husband really enjoyed it and said it was a keeper. Will definitely make again!
The next time I make this, I will use less thyme. Also, I used the immersion blender to make it easier to eat. It was delicious!
LOVE it! Will be our go to French onion for sure. We skipped the sherry and used 2 tsp Oregeno vs. the Thyme. Used Mozza on hand vs. Provolone turned out awesome
Easy to make and very delicious. I didnt have beef broth or stock, so substituted beef bullion cubes. Rich and delicious!
Excellent. I used dry red wine instead because that’s what I had on hand. This is a keeper. Even my teenager liked it.
Very good. Made as is and we LOVED it!
Wonderful taste can hardly wait for my Family to taste to eat this wonderful Soup!
Fantastic french onion soup!
Fantastic french onion soup!
It was very easy to make and my wife loved it. Definitely 5 stars for this Recipe!

I had to change a lot about this recipe, but it was a decent jumping-off point. First; caramalize the onions. It makes a HUGE difference. Second; MOAR GARLIC! IAlways add entirely too much garlic (unless you're allergic to it). Also, add the spices (Bay, thyme, tarragon, fresh cracked pepper) at this stage. Especially the bay and pepper. You want that infused into the butter, and, in turn, the onions. 

Also, once the onions are caramalized, add the sherry (and I did mushrooms) and let it evaporate, cooking into the onions and/or mushrooms. Next, NO MORE SALT. You reeeeally don't need that much salt. You won't be able to taste the delicious food you just made.

Made this exact to the recipe and found it was too buttery for our tastes. It lacked a richness and boldness that we'd prefer. We used quality ingredients which came through but apparently too smooth a flavor profile. On the whole, the recipe works and was simple, but it doesn't deliver a punch. A two-star as that indicates that we "didn't like it" as we didn't want to finish the last bowl leftover after a few days (food waste - I know!). Your tastes may vary.
Turned out wonderful. We used red and yellow onions from our garden.
Too much thyme. Not a great soup over all. Will not use this recipe again.

Definitely need to caramelize the onions for the best flavor. We used Swansons beef stock instead of broth, added a tbsp of Worcestershire sauce and one clove of minced garlic. Not a fan of thyme so substituted oregano and used toasted garlic bread for croutons. This recipe is way better than anything we have experienced in the local restaurants so we will be definitely make this again!
This turned out Great!! Was really easy to make. I did brown the onion slightly and it was very tasty. Will definitely make it again. It is now a family favorite!

I love this soup. I have made it with vegetable broth for vegetarian friend, and with chicken broth. By far it is best with beef broth. I use fresh thyme and the shot of sherry adds an extra layer of richness. We keep French bread slices in the freezer just in case. 
Tried it this week with red onions...delish.
amazing and so easy

It turned out fabulous! However, I substituted one can of the beef broth for a can of chicken broth. Also, I added a half a cup of red wine instead of the sherry. I sautéed the onions until they were translucent and soft. I used 2 1/2 medium sized yellow onions.

This soup is simply delicious! I did take the advice of others and caramelize the onions a little bit, and I think it makes for a much richer suit. I did leave out the Sherri. And I used a mixture of provolone, Asagio, Parmesan and mozzarella cheeses?. I love how quick and easy it is to make.?

I really have no idea why Lori says NOT to brown the onions? Caramelized onions are the hallmark of French onion soup! Oh, I also caramelized more onions than called for. I also used beef stock in place of broth, I just think stock gives a much richer beef flavor! Finally, I used Gruyere cheese and I toasted the bread that I put on top...this suggestion came from another reviewer so I thought I'd try it and, OMG, That's how I will do it from now on!!
Thanks Lori for the basic recipe!!

I used white onion, since it was what I had in the pantry. I added a little Parsley in the soup and as a topping, and some oregano. It can do without the oregano, but it wasn’t a detractor. I used Gruyere, and a slice of Havarti, with grated Parmesan before broiling.

Love this soup.
Tip to tearless onion cutting, is to freeze them first and only take one out of freezer at a time.
Did cut back on butter a little and only used enough oil to coat bottom of pan. 
Added just a pinch of corn starch, to thicken the soup, to a little bit of the beef broth BEFORE it is heated so it won't stick together.
Put a pinch of salt and sugar on onions while cooking. I used a little minced garlic too. Make sure to make translucent but get them golden caramelized. 30-60 min on med heat.
Use some kind of wine to de-glaze pan is needed not optional.
Used 1tbsp of Worcester sauce and 1 bouillon cube with 4 cups beef broth. I used 1 bay leaf and dried thyme but would do fresh if possible. I Brought to boil then down to light simmer for 20-60 min covered.
After done cooking, I added shredded parmesan, like you put on spaghetti, to the soup itself and added shredded cheese to bottom of my bowls before adding soup, then the toasted bread with cheese on top. (No swiss) since I had Brie cheese this time I use that.

An excellent onion soup. I made it per the recipe and it was wonderful. I made it a second time but added a tbsp of Worcestershire a tbsp of better than bouillon and I preferred the added flavor depthness
I made this for my family and they loved it! I accidentally put more thyme than it calls for and had no Swiss cheese, so just used more provolone, but it still turned out amazing!!! Thanks!
The best batch I've ever made. I did have to Q's New York style sharp cheddar cheese with the shredded provolone and it came out fabulous
Loved it. Just loved it all I have to say. Kidding. I thought it tasted as if I were to eat it at a restaurant ,maybe even better. My family thought the same.
Absolutely delicious! I used sweet onions but yellow would have been better! Next time!
Good! I did caramelize onions and added a little flour to thicken juice a tiny bit and a dash of Kitchen bouquet!

Made this soup out of spare parts in my kitchen and what I could get my hands on during Covid-19. I had 2 large yellow onions and 2 smaller ones so chopped those up. I used leftover day old Malbec wine instead of sherry, and ended up adding more beef broth since I poured too much wine into the broth. In the end, this soup was so delicious and reminded me of my favorite French onion soup from Le Bistro on the Norwegian Getaway cruise ship.

Hubby said this was the best French onion soup he’d ever had!!! It is a great recipe as written, however, with a few modifications, you can knock it out of the park! Based on other suggestions these are the modifications I made; reduced the butter to1/4 cup (it’s plenty!) I sliced 2 brown and 3 sweet vidalia onions into 1/2” slices and caramelized with the butter. About 30-40 min. I then added 2 cloves of garlic and cooked until fragrant. Then I added 1/2 Cup Cabernet Sauvignon and cooked until reduced by half. Then I added 1 TBS Worcheshire. For the broth I used 5 TBS Better Than Bullion beef and a total of 10 cups of water. (In a glass 2 cup measuring cup I put in 2 cups of h2o and microwaved it until boiling then I added the 5 TBS of Better Than Bullion and mixed it until dissolved). Add to the soup. Let it all simmer for about an hour. In the meantime, I sliced a French baguette into 1/2” slices and toasted them on a baking sheet in a 375 degree oven until crispy. @10 minutes.I placed my ramekins on a baking sheet and ladled the soup in each one, leaving 1/2” or so headroom. I then placed a couple pieces of the toasted baguette on top of the ramekins of soup. Top each with a slice of each Swiss cheese, Provolone and a sprinkling of freshly grated Parmesan cheese. Carefully set the tray of ramekins under the broiler for about 3 minutes until cheese is melted and just starting to brown. Watch carefully so it doesn’t burn. This recipe is a real treat!!! I will make it again
I liked it. It was very simple. I cut the ingredients in half. I used half of a Vidalia onion and half a Red onion. I used vegetable broth and the remaining beef bullion that I had.(about a tsp).
I added a bit more butter, used fresh thyme, and more cheese!
